reviewText: While I was on the fence about Bit Blaster XL, the moderately fun (albeit simple) retro gameplay coupled with a price you can't argue with forces me to upvote.  This is pure arcade-style gameplay. The only 'permanent' upgrades are unlockable ships that you gain from earning in-game currency. The only real goal is getting a high score.  Essentially, the whole game plays on a single scren. If you hit the edge of the screen, you die. The primary mechanic or novelty is the shooting mechanic. While it is toggle-able, you are constantly shooting which obviously depletes ammo stores - which you replenish by pickups dropped when enemies are killed. There are various temporary gun upgrades sort of reminiscent of Contra (not sure why that game comes to mind, but it does).  Look, are you going to dump hours and hours into this? Probably not. But for about a buck, you get a pretty wicked game to pass the controller around with friends and try to beat each other's score.

reviewText: Simple and fun arcade game that is worth way more than 1 dollarBit blaster XL is an addicting arcade game where players shoot enemies that get progressively harder, while switching out different weapons to do thier bidding. The ship they control is constantly moving forward, to dodge enemies and thier bullets the player must turn with the right and left arrow keys as well as can use a boost, or could take the hit with a shield. As players progress in the game they recieve ammo, which allows them to keep firing at enemies to get more and more ammo and the game is infinite. Instead of an ammo drops, RNG gods can grant the player a shiny golden coin! These coins can be used to buy a different ship, some ships are bigger with more shields, smaller with more speed, and is up to the player on how they wish to play the game. Along with that choice, the developer gives more choices to players, as you can actually toggle auto-firing OFF! Which leads to more strategic gameplay that lessens the arcade feel the game has.  Pros:+Unique weapons +Easy to learn +Unlockable ships +Manual Fire mode +Soundtrack +Full controller support +Steam trading cards, achievements, AND leaderboards  Cons:-Repetitive gameplay -End game isnt as enjoyable  Judgement: 8/10 Its simple, its fun, its cheap. I highly recommend to all players that enjoy arcade games, and even if you dont its cheap, enjoyable, and a great game to have in your steam library, get it :)  For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!

reviewText: This game is really fun to play and well-designed! There is enough variety in the ships you unlock to make playing with each a slightly different experience. Game keeps challenging your mind and focus, as you have to watch out for collisions and be careful not to run out of ammo while aiming and controlling the speed. reviewText: Though incredibly simple, this is pobably the best game I have ever purchased on Steam for less than £1.00. Bit Blaster XL is a space themed shoot-em-up, a concept almost as old as video games themselves so you know exactly what you're buying and thus I don't need to explain any further. Despite the fact that it is a theme that has been done to death, this is surprisingly a lot of fun to play and has proven to be incredibly addictive.  Your ammunition rapidly depletes as a result of your ship constantly auto-firing forcing you to collect the ammo power-ups throughout all of the hazards on screen, which becomes very challenging after a certain point in time. Collectables include coins to unlock other ships in your arsenal and different temporary weapons, ranging from rapid fire, bouncing projectiles, explosives and even a light saber esque weapon, plus many more.  As your points increase, so does the difficulty, things become very hectic after the 10,000 point margin always keeping you on your toes. One word of advice though, if you're going to play this, I would highly recommend using a controller, it's tough to maneuver using a keypad.  I couldn't recommend this game highly enough, especially since it's incredibly cheap. There is much, much worse you could be using your £0.79 for. The awesome soundtrack alone is worth more than that.

reviewText: Hi.  I LOVE spaces hooters. Bit Blaster XL is a mix of Asteroids, Robotron and Berzerk. Camera is over the space room full of enemies. You have a spaceship with limited ammo. The trick is: better weapons needs more ammo. Even without combo point system you had to destroy someting constantly, because every dead enemy drops ammo and you need it to feed a weapon. If you're out of ammo, you're back to a standard pew pew laser.  It's a very simple, but effective mechanic. It's always risk vs reward, so you can play safe, or beat a crap out of hi-score. Game is really hard, because most weapons shoots only in the direction that you are flying (like in Berzerk), but enemies of course are all over you and can aim. So it is a challenge, like any other arcade style shooter, but not unfair and I feel I can handle it.  Have fun.  ---------------------------------------------------------------  EDIT: Last upgrade is really nice. More powerups (including new shelds), ability to speed up, enemies respawns more often. I feel I'm dying much faster, but scoring faster, too.

The challenge comes when you have to shoot enemies to get more ammo/points, and collect powerups. There are multiple ships you can upgrade to by collecting coins which are dropped by various enemies. There are also various types of enemies in the game, and to up the challenge you can disable autofiring and fire yourself. Both keyboard and controller are supported, and my Steam controller worked right away without even having to open Big Picture mode [ymmv].  The game (as of version 2.02) is somewhat sparse in the settings menu, but it gets the job done.  I have tested it on Linux, and it runs very well. reviewText: This game is short and sweet. If you're using a keyboard, the controls are limited to 3 buttons: you steer your ship with the left and right arrow keys, and use your boost with the spacebar. There's an auto-fire option where the ship continuously shoots, or there's a manual-fire option where you can press ctrl or alt to fire a shot. If you don't want to use a keyboard to play, you can also use a gamepad.  The gameplay is simple; You shoot the enemies to score points, and each enemy drops a green ammo pickup that slowly moves towards you. It may seem easy, but scoring really high becomes difficult since you can't stop your ship, and some enemies shoot (slow moving) bullets towards you.  My one and only complaint is that there is no pause button, but on an arcade-styled game like this that's meant to be short and replayed, the lack of a pause function is practically a non-issue unless you're going for a marathon score run.  For what Bit Blaster XL has to offer, I'd say it is definitely worth the price and I strongly recommend it as a great casual game. One last thing I'd like to mention is that the developers for this game actively reply to any potential issues and questions, which I think is a huge plus.

reviewText: You are the newest pilot in a specially trained devision of the army trained to fly rocketships. You are one of the last lines of defense that your planet has. You step in the rocket and see the platform slowly move further away from you. And then you see them. The asteroids. You start firing at them, destroying them and defending earth as much as you can. You see your first support from earth in a glowing, colorful ball. You fly your ship towards it, to find out it is an upgrade for your gun. You install it and find out its power. After a while, earth asks you to start collecting coin-like alien material that, once back down on earth, can be used to upgrade your ship. Sometime later, you send a packet of about 5 coins down to earth, and in return you get another ship. Smaller, faster, it has faster firing capabilites and is better in many ways. You defend earth with all your might, recieving support in the form of new spaceships and gun upgrades when you see the aliens ships firing towards you. You start firing towards them too, trying to dodge the asteroids as much as you can. As you slowly become more focused on the situation, you start to find out how to fly effectively and how to dodge asteroids to only focus on the spaceships. You realize your entire team has been taken out by the aliens.  You are earth's last hope. You are the Bit Blaster.  (That was a story I wrote for the plot of the game: don't presume it is official, that is just what I like to imagine it being :])  Overall, this is a very good game for its value. It has great music, is a decent difficulty and has a lot of features that take a little bit of time to learn. Overall, it is simple but has great mechanics and is a rewarding experience when you finally reach the drop. I highly recommend this game to a lot of people, especially those who like the game Asteroids (the arcade game, you know)

reviewText: Ah. Where do I even start?  Bit Blaster XL is a modern take on some of the old retro-sytle arcade games you played back in the 80s(yes i'm not from the 80s. mind you. I was born 2001) there is 8 ships, and each has its' own custom speed,fire rate, shield durability, and song! with each ship it is a little different than the last considering you only have a max of 100 ammo, but there is an option for manual shooting if you want more of a challenge.  Not to mention since each ship is different you have to adapt to all of them. they each have a different play style. it's kinda like you just got a new game and need to learn how it works. The game has great graphics, and even if you have a $200 laptop that's OK! this game barely needs much at all. there is around a dozen or more powerups and each is different. once you run out of ammo with a powerup then you have to collect more ammo, but you lose the powerup, but don't worry. you can pick up ammo with the powerup: just be careful! don't run into the walls! there is a bit of variety when it comes to enemies. the higher your score: the stronger then enemies(and the more too! might I add).  You unlock ships by using coins which randomly drop from enemies and some enemies only drop coins. What to talk about next? Ah Yes! The songs are also great! they have a real 8-Bit feel to them(Props and kudos to Spiff Tune. he did an amazing job on the songs. if you're reading this; good job man!). there is such a variety with this game and no two games will be the same! all the things fit really well together and it really feels like an 80s game!  And that should just about wrap things up here! I hope this review helped and if there is anything I should add please let me know! other than that I want to thank the dev for being active and really listening to what we have to say! I can only imagine how hard it is to be a single dev, but hey! no one can argue with you! Good job Nickervision! I can't wait for a possible sequel!

reviewText: Bit Blaster XL is an arcade game in the style of Asteroids and Geometry Wars.  This game can get pretty brutal at points, especially at the beginning when you don’t have very good ships. You collect coins and can buy new ships that move faster, have more shields, or fire faster. They vary enough that you can find the one you are most comfortable using. However, most of the time you will just end up using Ship 7 or 8 as they have the most shield, fire the quickest, and move the fastest.  There are also weapon pickups that change the way you fire. Some cause explosions, some give you a shotgun style blast, some make you fire incredibly fast. The amount of pickups does become a bit redundant as there are two pickups that are really overpowered and make the others pointless.  You will end up only using about 3 different pickups.  One of the biggest problems with this game is the controls. Using a controller still made it hard to be accurate at points and the keyboard was even worse. The ships move way to quick at points and make it hard to be precise. I’m not sure if it was just me but this ended up infuriating me at points. Another problem is how slow the score rises. If you go for every achievement, getting to 75k can take a while. You just don’t get enough points. This is quite disheartening when you think you are doing really well and you have destroyed a load of enemies to find out that you only have 15k points.  I honestly didn’t really enjoy my time playing this game for the reasons that i gave above, however i know that some people will enjoy this game.  It is quite fun if you played it to kill 10 minutes every now and then, but as someone who played this for a 5 hour sitting one time, it might start to bug the hell out of you, If you think this looks fun, go for it. Its pretty cheap and you will get your moneys worth in the end. 5/10.

reviewText: Ah. Where do I even start?  Bit Blaster XL is a modern take on some of the old retro-sytle arcade games you played back in the 80s(yes i'm not from the 80s. mind you. I was born 2001) there is 8 ships, and each has its' own custom speed,fire rate, shield durability, and song! with each ship it is a little different than the last considering you only have a max of 100 ammo, but there is an option for manual shooting if you want more of a challenge.  Not to mention since each ship is different you have to adapt to all of them. they each have a different play style. it's kinda like you just got a new game and need to learn how it works. The game has great graphics, and even if you have a $200 laptop that's OK! this game barely needs much at all. there is around a dozen or more powerups and each is different. once you run out of ammo with a powerup then you have to collect more ammo, but you lose the powerup, but don't worry. you can pick up ammo with the powerup: just be careful! don't run into the walls! there is a bit of variety when it comes to enemies. the higher your score: the stronger then enemies(and the more too! might I add).  You unlock ships by using coins which randomly drop from enemies and some enemies only drop coins. What to talk about next? Ah Yes! The songs are also great! they have a real 8-Bit feel to them(Props and kudos to Spiff Tune. he did an amazing job on the songs. if you're reading this; good job man!). there is such a variety with this game and no two games will be the same! all the things fit really well together and it really feels like an 80s game!  And that should just about wrap things up here! I hope this review helped and if there is anything I should add please let me know! other than that I want to thank the dev for being active and really listening to what we have to say! I can only imagine how hard it is to be a single dev, but hey! no one can argue with you! Good job Nickervision! I can't wait for a possible sequel!

reviewText: Bit Blaster isn't the best game out there, but it's fun enough that I got about an additional hour of enjoyment out of it for the purposes of this re-reveiw (see below for old reveiw).  While many of my old criticisms still stand, the recent update done by the developer Nickervision added enough new content that I found it more worthwhile to play (now on my newly unlocked fourth ship which I quickly came to prefer over the previous three).  Much of the combat is as I described before, but I'd like to reiterate how the powerups are the best part of this game. They often change the way the game is played in ways both large and small. with some, the best strategy is to be calm and fire conservatively like with the blue explosive power up, while with others, the best strategy is to spray and pray, like with the richocheting pink power up. I quickly found ones that I prefered. My favorite was always the purple one that acted like a short range shot gun.  Of course, minor critisisms became more pronounced the longer I played. It's often very easy to take multiple hits in quick succession for ships with shields due to the lack of invinsibility frames. The scoreboard is pretty meaningless and hard to get to considering this is a game where the only goal is to get a high score.  In fact, after a while, the game gets pretty samey. Since the score is such an after thought, the only reason to play the game is for the game's own sake. Once every round of bit blasting feels like the last one, it starts to get boring. After the first few ship unlocks, it takes too long to get the next ship for that to be a proper motivation to keep playing.  Still, for all it's faults, I had a decent ammount of fun with it. For the price of a dollar, I think it's worth a try, especially if it's on sale.  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Ship combat is not Bit Blaster's strength. Bullets only eject from the front of the ship, and the ship can only go forward with an incredibly large turning radius. It's clunky. That's not to say that you can't get good at it, it's just not fun to get good at.  What is Bit Blaster XL's strength then? well, it has some kick ♥♥♥ music. That alone kept me going for longer than I would normally have.  I think the real strength of Bit Blaster is its power up system. Each power up is completely unique and has the potential to be completely game changing. Sure, there are the mundane ones that just make you fire faster or also shoot from your butt, but there are also the ones that make large balls the same size as your ship bounce off the walls of the screen, filling the entire thing with your bullets, or the ones that make explosives that blow up everything in front of your ship, or the one that gives you a short range laser that makes you have to get up in the business of anythin you want to kill.  They're pretty sweet, I'll admit.  Still, it's not enough to carry the game for me. The terrible controls really hinder the game, and the space ships that I unlocked before quitting were pretty lack luster. Maybe someone else will find it more fun than I did.

reviewText: A great little arcade games where you fly around, steering left and right(you're always moving forward), speed boosting, and shooting, since your ship is always shooting without your input. This game is really fun and simple. There are plenty of weapon pickups with unique attacks, my favorite being the beam, though it has the trade off of being short.  There are unlockable ships too, with varying size, shooting speed, move speed, and shields, which determines how many hits you can take before death, though crashing into a wall will always insta-kill you.  As you play the game, little gold coins will either drop from enemies, or simply roll on screen. Collect them and use them to unlock the ships. First ship unlock costs 5 points, next one costs 10, and they keep increasing in cost by 5, with the current(as of this review) final ship costing 30.  This game is just incredibly fun and for only a dollar at most. I definitely recommend it.

reviewText: TL:DR - Short and sweet. Classic asteroidy action. Good fun.  Now for the real review.  Bit Blaster XL is a retro arcadey Asteroids-esque game. It's an incredibly well executed fast paced bullet hell, with a catchy arcade soundtrack and unlockables. Whats not to like? It takes a while to get used to the controls, simple as they are, so be prepared to smash into the walls a lot. There are a large number of upgrades to choose from, although they could be more accurately described as powerups given they appear at random. That said, without experience it is hard to tell what powerup does what, or even which ones would be useful. The fact that some of the powerup sprites are only differentiated by colour is not helpful, so be prepared also to spend a fair chunk of time swearing because you let the amazing Explosion powerup go for the terrible version of the shotgun powerup (for example).  The game also swiftly gets incredibly cluttered, although as I said this is a bullet hell game so what were you expecting. For this there are several useful powerups and several not so useful. Heres a list of my top 5 and one I never take, even if it means sticking with the peashooter they give you at the start. (Note: These are all my own names, given the lack of andy form of guide)   1.) Explosion/Lightsaber (Blue E and Green L respectively) depending on which ship you use. Fast ships go for lightsaber as a swift turn can cut through the bigass splitting asteroids really quickly, netting you a nice chunk of ammo. Otherwise go for the explosion, as it lingers for a bit and any enemies that walk into the field left  blow up too. 2.) Don't get me wrong, both of the above are incredibly useful on any ship, it's just that faster ships perform better with the lightsaber than slower ones. 3.) Homing balls (Orange H). This fires (at a cost of 5 ammo) an orange blob at a random enemy on screen, and lets you keep firing the standard gun. Useful, and given that each ammo drop gives you 5 ammo, as  long as you're quick enough this can go on forever. 4.) Ricochet (sorry can't remember the icon for this one). As the name says. Very useful, especially later, as there is no way they can miss with the number of enemies on screen. 5.) I agonized for a bit over this one, because there are a couple that are really good. But the last one is Multi (Orange M). This fires a shot to the front and the back. This is especially useful given the turning circle of some of the ships.  The one you should never, ever, ever go for :- M♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (Purple M). The only boost this has, as far as I can tell, is making the ammo pickups drift towards you slightly quicker. Given that they do this anyway, and that it slows down the speed of your main weapon firing, it's just useless. Unless you want a challenge.

reviewText: For the record, before you read this look at my playtime and decide for yourself how many grains of salt this review is worth. It could be completely irrelevant to you. Anyways, I just want to start off saying you should buy this game. For 99 cents, it's got a fair amount of content. And it's a simply good game. The gameplay is fair, with the enemies actually having a good ramping difficulty curve. The ships are fun to unlock, albeit the way you unlock them is a bit strange. You see, you collect coins to unlock them, but the coins are a random drop from enemies, so it's sort of non-linear. The pixelated graphics look nice, and the particles... are excellent. The music is fine, but I like some more than others (Looking at you, ship #4). Overall, this is a simply fun game to play and is definitely worth it.  However, with that being said, no game is perfect. And there is 1 complaint I feel I should express. The power-ups make no sense from my view. Their icon is a simple colored circle with a letter in it, so good luck guessing what it is. However, once you use it it's pretty simple to figure out what that letter stands for. R = Rapid Fire, L = Lazer, H = Helper(?). So the symbols aren't a huge issue, but their balance is a bit off. For example, remember the Helper power-up I just mentioned? It is very overpowered. It's an AI-controlled projectile that auto-tracks the enemies around you and kills them. It can only hit once, but one time I just dodged enemies while it ground everything into a mushy pulp, racking up ~2000 points in score. That score did not feel rewarding, it did most of the work. And then there's the Magnet power-up, which I avoid like the plague. It constantly sucks ammo, and because of the ammo cooldown timer you cannot fire right when you press the button to fire, making it difficult to time your shots. And it's magnet powers aren't that impressive, as you're constantly moving away from the ammo.  TL;DR: Buy the game if you can, it's amazing, avoid the purple M.

reviewText: Genuinly one of the best shmup's I've ever played. The fantastic pixel art blends perfectly with the really catchy music that chirps away as you blast astriods and enemy spaceships.  The sense of progression is simple, as it should be in this retro style game, and doesn't feel overwhelmingly grindy - although it is essentially what you're doing. The weapons really stand out too - Some are your average three-way bullets, or your slightly bigger ones - but there are some really intuitive weapons too. My personal favourite is the lazor sword, which is bloody perfect as long as you manage your ammo.  Oh - This game also has ammo. Yeah, it's an odd mechanic to add into an endless shooter like this, but it works really well. You can have your shooting set to automatic, which is really handy when you just want to focus on getting out of annoying situations, but I prefer to play with this turn off. One addition that I feel would really help the game feel much smoother would be the ability to toggle this function on and off during a game - Maybe binding it to 'Y' or 'B' on the controller? That way, one can switch their focus from gaining points and swerving to dodge the debris that quickly fills your screen.  Overall, if you think you like the look of this, you'll probably have tonnes of fun with it. And why not? It's under £1~  -Ashe

reviewText: Definitely not the best game on steam, not even the best of its genre. The dev was very nice when I talked to him and you cant beat the $1 price, but in its current state the game doesnt engage me enough to keep me coming back.  Its difficult for me to make a negative review because I cant hide behind the lens of anonymity since I’ve talked to the dev, but I can’t in good conscious recommend this game in its current state and I will try to give an accurate overview on why:  -uninspired developer art, pixel art can look very good if done well, but the current art is almost temp art, simplistic to the point of being boring.  -completely average uninteresting powerups. Other than the lightsaber, all powerups amount to different colored pixels, travelling in different patterns. Also there are no real upgrades in this game, other than a shield. Powerups are always the same and disappear when you run out of ammo, so no upgrading your weapon or anything like that.  -little to no satisfaction/ user feedback. Destroying things in this game doesn’t create huge explosions or display (500 POINTS!, COMBO) no things just sort of split or disappear creating a few white pixels around them, when they are destroyed. This makes the game feel unsatisfying to play and there is not a feeling of accomplishment.  -awkward movement. Controls do not feel smooth, it is like trying to pilot an r/c car with a dying battery. When you play a game with fluid controls you really feel in control of your character, this game is the opposite. Auto fire is on by default so you don’t have control over your shots and waste 90% of your ammo, and the ships have a turning radius of a large boat.  I love the arcade, score attack genre, but this is not an example of a game that has done this well. I only have <30 mins in this game and some users may think this invalidated my review, but this is precisely the point, I have tried to play the game many time and am just not interested, I feel like I have experienced everything this game has to offer in 20 mins of playtime. A good score attack game keeps you coming back, this one feel extremely unsatisfying.  Here are some games I think are much better examples of the arcade/score attack genre and I recommend you check out: Geometry Wars, Super House of Dead Ninjas, RaidenX (Free online flash game), Super Crate Box.  I wish the dev the best and I mean no ill will with this review, I just want to give an accurate view about my opinions on his game. I gave him some suggestions that I would love to see implemented, and I am certainly willing to give this game another chance and re-review it if any of my criticisms have changed. If you are enjoying the game in its current state then more power to you.
